subject: Re: [junit] Feedback requested: Impending changes to RunListener
msgSnippet: ... Somebody could do like I did for find bugs annotations though https://github.com/stephenc/findbugs-annotations A bit of a pain reconstructing clean room,
messageBody:
On Wednesday, 6 February 2013, Kevin Cooney wrote:

> On Wed, Feb 6, 2013 at 11:22 AM, Stephen Connolly <
> stephen.alan.connolly@... <javascript:;>> wrote:
>
> > **
> >
> >
> > There are some legal people who have issues with some of the licenses on
> > some of those annotations jars
> >
> It looks like jcip-annotations uses Creative Commons, which is not
> recommended to be used to license software. That pretty much seals it for
> me.


Somebody could do like I did for find bugs annotations though
https://github.com/stephenc/findbugs-annotations
A bit of a pain reconstructing clean room, but can be done.

Iirc what stopped me at the time is the jcip annotations were being put
into a jsr and that is still stalled afair


>
> So it looks like we will either go with our own annotation or allow any
> annotation named "ThreadSafe" (in which case, JUnit would have our own
> ThreadSafe annotation in an internal package).
>
> The only remaining question is whether people expect APIs to behave
> differently based on whether the objects passed to them are of types
> annotated with a ThreadSafe annotation.
>
> One of the things I like about the JUnit annotations is that someone can
> look at the JavaDoc of the annotation to get a very clear idea of what
> behavior JUnit will give to the class/method/field/parameter with that
> annotation, plus it's easy to see what classes/methods/etc have special
> behavior (unlike JUnit3 where some behavior was based on the name of the
> method)
>
> -- Kevin
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
